Context:
The text describes two different programs offered by the college: a three-year diploma program in Construction Engineering Technology leading to a Bachelor's degree in Construction Management, and a four-year Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program.

The three-year diploma program requires students to complete Years 3 and 4 to receive their Bachelor's degree and the academic credential designation of Hons. B.Tech (Construction Management). Students are required to complete a mandatory field experience semester in the spring/summer of the third year, totaling a minimum of 450 hours of relevant fieldwork experience.

The four-year Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program combines theory, applied research, field study, and hands-on practical education. Students will receive the academic credential designation of Hons. B.Tech upon graduation. The program is recognized by the construction industry and fully accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS). Graduates can obtain Gold Seal Certification (GSC) offered by the Canadian Construction Association (CCA) to become certified superintendents, forepeople, estimators, project managers, owner's construction managers, and safety practitioners.

KEY INFORMATION:
1. Three-year diploma program: Leads to a Bachelor's degree in Construction Management after completion of Years 3 and 4. Minimum field experience requirement is 450 hours.
2. Four-year Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program: Combines technical and managerial skills, minimum field experience requirement is 450 hours. Graduates can obtain Gold Seal Certification (GSC).
3. Mandatory field experience semester in the spring/summer of the third year for both programs, totaling a minimum of 450 hours of relevant fieldwork experience.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T318 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program at the college prepares students for careers in various roles within the construction industry. These roles include, but are not limited to, construction manager, project manager, project coordinator, field engineer, site superintendent, estimator, project monitor, building science specialist, building condition assessor, construction sales manager, construction claims specialist, construction quality control specialist, construction health and safety specialist, construction cost consultant, developer, project controls specialist, site inspector, contractor, and subcontractor.

Construction managers need specialized skills to succeed in this industry, which is rapidly changing and requires professionals with a broad technical and business management background. The program is fully accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS), the Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB), and the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). Graduates of the program are qualified to obtain professional memberships in various construction management associations, such as CIQS, where they can obtain Professional Quantity Surveyors (PQS) or Construction Estimator Certified (CEC) designation. Additionally, graduates qualify for the Gold Seal Certification (GSC) offered by the Canadian Construction Association (CCA).

Context:
The Gold Seal Certification in the Canadian construction industry is available for superintendents, forepeople, estimators, project managers, owner’s construction managers, and safety practitioners. The certification is based on the candidate’s education, training, and professional work experience.

The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree is offered at George Brown College and is respected in the construction sector. Industry leaders believe that this program is an important component to ensure the continual requirement for construction professionals will be met. The construction industry is the largest employer in the Greater Toronto Area, and producing graduates with necessary construction-specific skills will help strengthen its long-term success.

Quotes from industry leaders:
- Temple Harris, vice-chairman, Gillam Group: "The introduction of the Construction Management program at George Brown College is the next stage of development of professionalism in the construction industry."
- Christopher Rick, PCL Constructors, Canada Inc.: "In order to provide the necessary leadership, we need to staff our projects with construction professionals. Therefore, we believe the four-year degree program in Construction Management at George Brown College is an important component to ensure our continual requirement for construction professionals will be met."
- James Zippel, general manager, Electrical Service & Projects, Ainsworth: "As the industry expands and continues to change, it is imperative that individuals overseeing and managing construction projects are properly trained in all facets of the business."
- Greg Kozicz, president, Alberici Constructors, Ltd.: "In our opinion, there continues to be a real need for improved and advanced education and training in the construction sector and an improved method of attracting and retaining the best and brightest of our future generations. We submit that this program is a significant step in the right direction toward achieving these goals."
- Michael George, president, Trisura Insurance: "The urgency for a program of this nature is fuelled by the rapid change in our construction industry and the fact that it is becoming more technology-driven each day. Having graduates of such competency will help to raise the bar in terms of the knowledge and capabilities of companies involved in the construction industry."

Context:
The text provides information about the required courses for a construction program offered by the college. Here are the facts extracted from the text:

1. Mike Van Volsen is an operations manager at Access Suspended Platforms Inc.
2. Semester 4 courses include BLDG 2081 (Structural Systems in Building Construction 1), BLDG 2082 (Structural Systems in Building Construction 2), BLDG 2204 (Commercial Construction Technology), and a Liberal Studies Elective.
3. Semester 5 courses include BLDG 2109 (Soils and Foundations), BLDG 2111 (Highrise Construction Technology), BLDG 2166 (Construction Graphics 2), BLG 3043 (Construction Health and Safety), BLGD 3045 (Heavy Construction 1), BLGD 3055 (Work Preparation 1), BSCI 3101 (Applications in Building Science), and a Liberal Studies Elective.
4. Semester 6 courses include BLDG 3167 (Construction Cost Control), BLDG 3168 (Capstone 1 – Bid Competition), BLDG 3169 (Work Term Preparation 2), BLDG 3175 (Heavy Construction 2), ECON 2005 (Macro and Micro Economics), and two Liberal Studies Electives.
5. A Summer Field Experience Semester includes TCOP 1001 (Work Term, 450 hours).
6. Semester 7 courses include BLDG 3152 (Economics of Project Development), BLDG 3170 (Preconstruction Cost Planning), BLDG 3177 (Applications in Building Information Modeling), and BLDG 3178 (Decision Analysis and Critical Thinking).
7. Semester 8 courses include BLDG 4021 (Construction Risk Management), BLDG 4050 (Sustainable Construction), BLGD 4150 (Capstone 2 – Industry Research), MGMT 4052 (Project), and various management courses such as MGMT 4050 (Construction Project Procurement 1), MGMT 4055 (Construction Labour Relations and Human Resources), and MGMT 4088 (Construction Business Management and Entrepreneurship).

Therefore, the college offers a construction program that includes courses in structural systems, soils and foundations, commercial and highrise construction technology, economics, cost control, health and safety, construction graphics, decision analysis, risk management, sustainable construction, work term preparation, and various management courses. The program lasts for eight semesters, including a summer field experience, and students are required to complete a certain number of hours in work terms.

Context:
Program Name: Construction Management Degree Completion Pathway
Courses:
- Capstone 2 – Industry Research (MGMT 4150)
- Project Financial Monitoring (MGMT 4052)
- Construction Project Procurement 2 (MGMT 4090)
- Leadership and Ethics for Construction Managers (MGMT 4091)

Additional Information:
- Field experience fee applies for the field experience semester.
- Program is subject to change.
- Eligibility: George Brown College students with a GPA of 3.0 or higher from the Construction Engineering Technology program (T105), or graduates from comparable programs at other Ontario colleges.
- Contact Information: 416-415-5000, ext. 6297, construction_degree@georgebrown.ca

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Use relevant media to communicate construction project information.
- Analyze past construction project performance for future improvement.
- Manage construction projects in a compliant, safe, ethical and sustainable manner.
- Apply management tools and techniques to execute construction projects on time and within budget.
- Recognize and value diversity in construction project execution.
- Develop high-functioning teams using effective leadership strategies.
- Analyze technical problems and develop solutions.
- Apply business, accounting and financial principles to manage construction costs.
- Evaluate key performance indicators of construction projects.
- Assess risks and devise risk mitigation strategies.
- Create and manage construction project documentation.
- Behave ethically consistent with professional codes of conduct, laws, policies and contracts.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $9,418.00
- International Tuition: $20,925.00
* † Additional costs are not specified in the text.

Context:
The Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management at George Brown College offers a program in Construction Management. The recommended computer configuration for this program includes a SATA Hard Drive (Storage), NVIDIA® GeForce RTX™ 2060 6GB GDDR6 display card, 802.11ac Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity with 2 x 2 ports (1x HDMI 2.0, 3x SuperSpeed USB 3.1 Gen 1 Type-A including 1x with PowerShare, 1x 2-in-1 SD / MicroMedia Card slot, and 1x Wedge lock slot). The minimum screen size requirement is 15.6 inches FHD(1920 x 1080) 300nits IPS Anti-Glare LED backlit display with a refresh rate of 144Hz. The audio has one combo headphone / microphone jack.

Domestic students are advised to apply through Ontario Colleges. The contact information for the Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management is: Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 6297; Email: construction\_degree@georgebrown.ca; Office hours are 8 a.m. – 4 p.m., room E228. The Centre for Construction and Engineering Technologies (CCET) Industry Liaison Office (ILO) hosts open houses typically in the autumn and spring. For more information, visit the Construction and Engineering Open House page.

George Brown College's Contact Centre can be reached at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.

Students are encouraged to attend on-campus information sessions to meet instructors and staff and ask questions about the program and their career options. Information sessions can be signed up for online. Related programs include Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) (T312), Construction Engineering Technology (T105), and Civil Engineering Technology (T164). Campus tours can also be booked online.

Prospective students are advised that many programs do not run on the Mac platform operating system, and therefore, a Mac laptop is not recommended for purchase. Applications can be made through Ontario Colleges. The contact information for general information about George Brown College is available through their Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
